raw_text:
Famed music director Viotti dies
 
 Conductor Marcello Viotti, director of Venice's famous La Fenice Theatre, has died in Germany at 50.
 
 Viotti, director of La Fenice since 2002, conducted at renowned opera houses worldwide including Milan's La Scala and the Vienna State Opera. His time at La Fenice coincided with its reopening in 2003 after it was destroyed by fire in 1996. He fell into a coma after suffering a stroke during rehearsals for Jules Massenet's Manon last week.
 
 He conducted some of the best orchestras in the world including the Berlin Philharmonic and the English Chamber Orchestra. Viotti was born in Switzerland and studied the piano, cello and singing at the Lausanne Conservatory. His career breakthrough came in 1982 when he won first prize at the Gino Marinuzzi conducting competition in Italy. Viotti established himself as chief conductor of the Turin Opera and went on to become chief conductor of Munich's Radio Orchestra. At La Fenice Viotti was widely acclaimed for his production of the French composer Massenet's Thais and some of his other productions included Giuseppe Verdi's La Traviata and Richard Strauss's Ariadne auf Naxos.
 
 The last opera he directed at La Fenice was Massenet's Le Roi de Lahore. Viotti's debut at the New York's Metropolitan Opera came in 2000 with Giacomo Puccini's Madame Butterfly, followed by La Boheme, La Traviata and Fromental Halevy's La Juive. Giampaolo Vianello, superintendent of the Fenice Theatre Foundation, said: "I am filled with extreme sadness because, other than a great artist, he is missed as a friend - a main character in the latest joyous times, during the rebirth of our theatre." Viotti's last public performance was on 5 February when he conducted Vincenzo Bellini's Norma at the Vienna State Opera.

His career spanned several decades, including winning the Gino Marinuzzi conducting competition in 1982 and becoming chief conductor of the Munich Radio Orchestra and Turin Opera.
He made his debut at New York's Metropolitan Opera in 2000 and was mourned by colleagues who recognized him as a friend and a major part of La Fenice's revival.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: Marcelllo Marcello Viotti, a legendary music director of La Fenice Theatre in Venice, has passed away in Germany at the age of 50 following a stroke during his rehearsals for Jules Massenet's "Manon."

Known for his extensive orchestral career and numerous productions, including "Le Roi de Lahore," "Le Juive," "La Traviata," and "Ariadne auf Naxos," Viotti has become synonymous with the art of opera conducting.

tinyllama:1.1b: Famed music director Marcello Viotti died in Germany after suffering a stroke while conducting La Fenice's comeback production of Manon in 2017.
He was considered one of Europe's leading orchestral conductors and had performed with some of the best orchestras in the world, including the Berlin Philharmonic and the English Chamber Orchestra.
Viotti established himself as chief conductor of Turin Opera and went on to become chief conductor of the Munich Radio Orchestra.
He is widely celebrated for his production of La Traviata by Giacomo Puccini at the New York Metropolitan Opera in 2000, which featured legendary soprano Renée Fleming and earned him an Emmy Award.
Viotti's last public performance was a concert conducted by his former colleague, Riccardo Muti, in Vienna in May of 2017.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Conductor Marcello Viotti, renowned for his work with renowned opera houses and orchestras throughout Europe, tragically passed away at the age of 50.
He was celebrated for his skillful direction at La Fenice, a Venetian theatre that reopened in 2003 after undergoing extensive restoration.

Viotti's time at La Fenice coincided with its reopening, and his conducting at renowned opera houses such as Milan's La Scala and the Vienna State Opera further solidified his reputation as a versatile and influential conductor.
During his tenure at La Fenice, Viotti conducted some of the best orchestras in the world, including the Berlin Philharmonic and the English Chamber Orchestra.
He also established himself as a chief conductor with notable achievements, including winning first prize at the Gino Marinuzzi conducting competition in Italy.
His tenure at La Fenice included performances of Giuseppe Verdi's La Traviata, Richard Strauss's Ariadne on Naxos, and Mozart's Le Roi de Lahore.
The last opera Viotti directed at La Fenice was Massenet's Le Roi de Lahore, followed by performances of La Bohème, La Traviata, and from Giacomo Puccini's Madame Butterfly.
Despite his tragic passing, his contributions to the world of classical music will be remembered as significant and inspiring.

The La Fenice Theatre Foundation is filled with extreme sadness due to the loss of Viotti, a beloved friend who was not only a main character during joyous times but also an iconic conductor in his own right.
